title: 109_hr6262
content:
The Act is titled the "Special Agent Scott K. Carey Public Safety Officer Benefits Enhancement Act." It includes provisions for educational assistance to officers disabled in the line of duty, amending eligibility criteria and application processes. SEC. 102. APPLICATIONS; APPROVAL. Amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 regarding applicants and dependents. SEC. 103. RETROACTIVE BENEFITS. SEC. 103. RETROACTIVE BENEFITS. Amends eligibility for assistance under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 for eligible dependents of public safety officers who die or become disabled in the line of duty on or after January 1, 1978. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to define 'eligible dependent' as the child or spouse of a public safety officer eligible for benefits, and 'public safety officer' includes those described in section 1204. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include individuals employed by government agencies empowered to investigate or arrest for felony offenses. TITLE II--SURVIVOR PENSIONS

SEC. 201. SURVIVOR PENSIONS. Part L of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is further amended to establish survivor pensions for the beneficiaries of deceased public safety officers. The Bureau is required to pay an annual pension to one or more survivors in addition to other benefits. Survivor pensions are established for beneficiaries of deceased public safety officers under Part L of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. An annual pension is paid to survivors, with 80% going to a surviving spouse, and varying percentages to surviving children based on the number of children. Survivor pensions for deceased public safety officers under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 include varying percentages for surviving children based on their number. If there is no surviving spouse or child, pensions are allocated to surviving parents. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 provides survivor pensions for deceased public safety officers. The pension amount varies based on the relationship of the survivor to the officer, with percentages allocated to surviving children, spouses, or parents. If there are no surviving children or spouses, the pension is paid to the parents in equal shares. If none of the above apply, a pension equal to 20 percent of the applicable amount is paid to a designated beneficiary or to the individual who survived the officer. The pension under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is payable to the designated beneficiary or the individual who survived the officer, without regard to marital status or any other status. SEC. 1223 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 outlines the pension amount for officers, which is determined based on the officer's annual base salary at the time of death or a minimum of $60,000, adjusted annually for cost of living. The Bureau adjusts the pension amounts each fiscal year based on the Consumer Price Index. The term 'child' in this subpart includes natural, illegitimate, adopted, posthumous, or stepchild of a deceased public safety officer. The Secretary of Education can award Public Safety Officer scholarships to eligible applicants attending eligible institutions for kindergarten through secondary school or postsecondary degree programs. Applicants must submit an application to receive the scholarship award. An eligible applicant must submit an application to the Secretary with a certification from the head of the public safety agency. The maximum scholarship award for kindergarten, elementary, or secondary school students is based on the average per pupil expenditure. The average per pupil expenditure for elementary and secondary education in the local area and the actual cost to the student for attendance at the school are considered for scholarship awards. The maximum scholarship award for postsecondary students is based on the average cost of attendance at a State university. The scholarship award under this title covers the actual cost of attendance for a State resident student at a State university, based on their academic workload, dependents, and housing type. The duration of the award for kindergarten, elementary, or secondary school students is determined by the time needed to complete a high school diploma. The Secretary determines the duration of scholarship awards for postsecondary students, with a maximum of 6 years for undergraduates and 3 years for postgraduates. The Secretary notifies applicants and institutions of award selection and conditions. Eligible institutions may serve as fiscal agents for award payments. SEC. 302. ADDITIONAL AWARD REQUIREMENTS. A student awarded a scholarship must maintain satisfactory progress in their course of study, remain drug-free, and attend classes regularly. Students must maintain satisfactory progress in their studies and attend classes regularly, with exceptions for approved absences such as vacation, illness, or military service. SEC. 303. AGREEMENTS WITH ELIGIBLE INSTITUTIONS. The Secretary is authorized to enter agreements with eligible institutions for students receiving scholarship awards under this title. The agreements include cooperation in carrying out the program, conducting periodic reviews of student eligibility, and implementing control and accounting procedures for fund disbursement. To ensure proper disbursement and accounting of funds paid to the institution under section 301(e). SEC. 304. TREATMENT OF SCHOLARSHIPS FOR FINANCIAL AID: Scholarships under this title won't affect eligibility for student financial assistance under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965.

SEC. 305. DEFINITIONS. The term "deceased or disabled officer" refers to a public safety officer who has died or become permanently disabled as a result of an injury sustained in the line of duty. The term "dependent child" includes a child of a deceased or disabled officer, whether a biological, stepchild, or adopted child. An eligible applicant for a scholarship award must be a public safety officer, eligible spouse, or dependent child of a deceased or disabled officer residing in a State. The dependent child must be under 25 years old at the start of the academic year. An eligible institution for scholarship purposes includes public or private schools from kindergarten to higher education, located in a State and complying with antidiscrimination laws. An eligible spouse is the legally married husband or wife of a deceased or disabled officer. The term "public safety officer" is defined as per the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "State" includes all states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and U.S. territories. TITLE IV--MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

SEC. 401. COMPENSATION IN CASE OF DEATH.

Amends Section 8133(b)(1) of title 5, United States Code by removing the condition of remarriage before age 55.

SEC. 402. BENEFITS DEFINITION CONFORMING AMENDMENT.

Amends Section 1204 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 by revising the definition clause.
